ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RETIREES ABOVE 55 YEARS OF AGE

(Admission in public hospitals)


    1. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for Health (a) how many retirees above 55 years of age were hospitalised from 1994 to 1996; (b) how many of them could not afford to pay their bills; and (c) how many of them received assistance from Medifund.

    The Senior Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, between 1994 and 1996, there were about 240,000 admissions in public hospitals for people above the age of 55. Of that group, about 15,000 indicated that they could not afford to pay the bills and were referred to Medifund for assistance. About 15,300 of them (or 98.7%) received assistance from Medifund.

APPLICATIONS UNDER PUBLIC ASSISTANCE SCHEME


    2. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for Community Development (a) how many applications were approved

under the Public Assistance Scheme in 1996 as compared to 1991 and (b) how much was given to the successful applicants.

MAJLIS UGAMA ISLAM SINGAPURA
(Collection of administrative fee from Muslims performing haj)


    3. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (a) why Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura collects $200 each from Muslims who are going to perform haj and (b) how much was collected from 1994 to 1996 and how the money was spent.

    Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, may I be allowed to reply in Malay?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Abdullah Tarmugi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, the administrative fee of $200 for each haj pilgrim helps pay the costs of the various administrative, medical and welfare services provided by MUIS to our pilgrims.

    MUIS helps to ensure that all the haj arrangements for Singapore pilgrims are smooth and incident-free. A team comprising Assistant Pilgrim Officers and a Religious Officer accompany the pilgrims during the pilgrimage to advise pilgrims on haj rituals, religious matters and welfare services.

    Sufficient medical supplies and equipment will be brought into Saudi Arabia during the haj. Several premises are rented in Makkah, Medinah and Mina to be used as clinics and offices. These clinics are managed and served by a team

Column: 821

of doctors and nurses from Singapore who are paid allowances. Two ambulances have been purchased to serve our pilgrims. From 1994 to 1996, the amount collected are as follows: 

     Year           Amount collected

                         $

     1994                740,421

     1995               823,156

     1996               970,900
The amounts collected, Mr Speaker, Sir, have to be supplemented by donations from MSE Angullia Wakaf for the purchase of medical supplies.

    Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Can I ask the Minister what is MUIS' stand on the group of pilgrims who went to the haj not through MUIS and whether MUIS intends to collect the same administrative fee of $200 from them? If not, what is MUIS' stand on these pilgrims if they were to seek help or services from the various doctors and welfare officers while they are in Makkah?

    Mr Abdullah Tarmugi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, the stand of MUIS in respect of such pilgrims is that MUIS would not accept nor encourage them to obtain any visa outside Singapore. This matter will be discussed further in the Committee of Supply.

    With regard to whether they are required to pay $200, so far, MUIS did not collect any such amount from them. If we do, it means we are providing recognition to them. This issue will have to be studied further. With regard to services rendered at Makkah, MUIS does not take into consideration whether or not the pilgrim pays the $200 administrative fee because MUIS will provide the necessary assistance when needed.

    Encik Ibrahim bin Othman(In Malay): How can we make this matter more equitable for those who have paid the $200 and those who have not paid the $200 administrative fee? Will they receive the same treatment?

1ST APRIL, 1997 TO 31ST MARCH, 1998


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [2nd Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head Q -

    The Chairman: Head Q - Ministry of Home Affairs. Amendment No. (1), Mr Chng.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast) : Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head Q of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the Minister for Home Affairs has recently announced that 32 new Neighbourhood Police Centres (NPCs) will be set up when the current Neighbourhood Police Posts (NPPs) are revamped. These NPCs will serve as one-stop centres to provide a comprehensive range of services. The Minister has also disclosed that currently, our NPPs are understaffed. The NPCs can solve this problem because 120 officers can man each NPC at any one time, compared with the current 15 officers per NPP in the 92 NPPs nationwide.

    Sir, I applaud the efforts of the Singapore Police Force to be constantly on the look-out to improve the manner we handle internal security of our country making Singapore safe for Singaporeans. My concern is that this very restructuring may compromise the security and safety of Singaporeans. In my view, the introduction of the NPCs is in actual fact a move to downsize the Police Force. I do

Column: 823

not believe for one moment that this is done to cut down employment of police officers, but rather, I believe the Ministry or the Police Force has got a manpower shortage problem.

    As with all employers in Singapore, the Singapore Police Force also faces a similar problem, ie, shortage of manpower. More so in the uniformed services as generally Singaporeans shun such jobs. I understand also the staff turnover is high which means that we have difficulty in keeping those already recruited into the Force. This problem, Sir, could perhaps be solved through several ways. One is of course the recruitment of non-Singaporeans which the Police Force is already doing. More should be done as there are well-trained police personnel who are more than happy to make Singapore their home.

    The other measure is the freeing of manpower from non-essential areas and deploying well-trained officers to jobs which are crucial to the effectiveness of the Police Force. I shall speak more on this subject when I move a separate amendment on the privatisation of services.

    A third and perhaps most important measure is to review the salaries and terms of service of the organisation. I am in support of this measure as we must not take our low crime situation for granted. This low crime situation is due mainly to the effectiveness of the police in deterrence and crime solving.

    This effectiveness must be maintained if we are going to give Singaporeans the Best Home. Peace time security is no less important than preparing for external defence. Hence, I am most concerned that the restructuring may mean that we see less foot patrols, less bicycle patrols and less policemen on the roads. Such presence may seem to be unproductive and wasteful. But it is these very efforts which deter crime. It is these efforts which give our citizens a sense of security and confidence. How can this be measured or valued? Just like how do we measure or value National Service. Our police, aptly named the Home Team, is constantly in

Column: 824

direct contact with Singaporeans and tourists alike and their morale and pride must be maintained at the highest level.

    Sir, this House would like to be assured by the Minister that the reorganisation will enable Singaporeans to continue to enjoy the safety and security which we currently have, and that his Ministry will do its utmost to make our Home Team into a world class Police Force, if there is such a measure.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, before I speak, I suppose I should say that I have no pecuniary interest when I refer to instances but, of course, I am drawing from my knowledge and experience at the Criminal Bar.
12.45 pm

    I propose to speak on the accountability of the uniformed organisations in this country to the public. We have heard often enough from the Ministers and from the PAP leaders of how the Government is transparent and accountable to the people. I think the time has now come for us to translate some of these utterances into positive steps to show that the Police are accountable, not only the Police but also the other uniformed organisations, are accountable to the people. I think it is time we gave some measure of control over what happens in this country to our people. And my party has been advocating this for some time now in its slogan "Power to the People".

    I wish to speak on the role of the Police Force. Sir, the Police, first and foremost, serve the public. They are here to look after the interest of the public and to protect them. They must not be seen, and it would be dangerous if they are seen, to be serving their political masters.

    Some years ago when we had a prosecution against the party, one police officer, who was in the witness stand, quite candidly said, "Anything that comes from a political party, I can't deal with it. I have to refer it to the Minister for instructions," although he had the power to deal with that particular application from the party. But that is not the point of my amendment today. My amendment is

Column: 825

about the complaints that are made, from time to time, by members of the public about violence used by the police officers whilst they are under questioning or in the custody of the police.

    At the moment, any such complaint is referred to the Internal Investigation Section of the police. It is investigated by police officers, although we are told it forms a separate branch of the police. But nothing is said about how the investigations are carried out and if there is any report, that report is not made known to the public or to the victim who made the complaint. He is merely told in a very curt note that there is no evidence of his complaint.

    Some four years ago, there was a boy of 14 who was taken in by the police and he was detained for about seven hours. And when he was finally released, he was found to have severe injuries on him. The father reported it to the Internal Investigation Section and later on consulted the solicitors. When the solicitors wrote to the Division for the names of the police officers who had interrogated the boy and in whose custody he had been for seven hours, the Divisional head refused to disclose the names of the officers, and this dragged on for some period of time.

    I think in the cause of transparency and accountability, it is time that the Ministry considered setting up a body outside the Police Force to consider complaints against the police by members of the public. In Britain, they have had for some time now what is known as a police watch committee. Is it not possible for us in Singapore, in this age, to have such committees in every police area, composed of respectable citizens living in that area and who would be responsible enough to act responsibly, to inquire into the complaints and to direct or to request any action to be taken, if action is to be taken? That would give our citizens and the public a greater measure of confidence in the Police Force, that there is an independent neutral body which will investigate any complaints made against the police by them. That would enhance

Column: 826

the role of the police in the eyes of the people, and they will no longer be looked upon as merely serving their political masters.

    Mr Kenneth Chen Koon Lap (Hong Kah): Sir, I do not know why the NCMP always refers to Britain. Why do we always have to follow Britain? I think the British have their own problems. Thank you very much, we can manage ourselves.

    Sir, the latest announcement by the Ministry on the pay review of the Police Force is anxiously awaited. I hope it will be positive. It will no doubt help to boost the morale of the Force but, more importantly, it will attract more aspiring young Singaporeans to make law enforcement as their career.

    The Police Force has always placed human resource as its top priority. It constantly upgrades the skill of the officers and reorganises the Force, in order to be more effective and to keep up with the ever changing situation in crime fighting. The recent move to form Neighbourhood Police Centres, by integrating the NPPs would go a long way to enhance the effectiveness of our men in uniform. On this, I am more optimistic than my colleague, Mr Chng.

    However, no matter how one reorganises, the Force will always require more able and dedicated recruits and with the scarce human resource in Singapore and with so many sectors competing for so few, it will always be difficult to attract young, dedicated people to the Force. I would therefore like to suggest that since not all posts in the Police Force have to be trained so vigorously to serve as law enforcement officers, it would seem a waste to deploy all those who have undergone such training to serve in duties which do not require such discipline and skill. I am referring to those officers being deployed to tasks such as issuing parking summons for minor traffic offences, clerical or administrative duties.

    In some countries, I understand, issuing summons for illegal parking or minor traffic offences is being privatised, or they engage retirees to carry out this task. As for clerical and administrative duties,

Column: 827

those who are engaged in the Police Force need not be from the uniformed group. They can be drawn from the civilian work force. This would mean that those who join the Police Force and have undergone vigorous training will be deployed only for active police duty, so as to maximise their effectiveness in the uniformed group.

    Encik Harun bin A. Ghani: Sir, may I seek a clarification from Mr Jeyaretnam? I thought Mr Jeyaretnam said that the Singapore Police and other personnel are not accountable to Singapore. Is he saying that police and uniformed personnel are not accountable to the people of Singapore? He said it in his introduction just now.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I thought I made it quite clear when I spoke that when the public have complaints against the Police, they are not told how the investigation was carried out, what statements were taken and the final report is not made known to the person who made the complaint. That is exactly what I mean when I say accountable. The Police have to be accountable to the people, and if the people have a grievance, then the Police should answer the people and account to them for their actions.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, I just like to make a point about Mr Jeyaretnam's comments just now on the complaint against the Police. He, of course, will know that there are always checks against the misuse or improper use of methods of interrogation by police officers, not only it is provided for in the Penal Code in respect of offences for oppressive questioning, the courts have also taken it upon themselves to monitor and to look at statements made by accused persons to police officers to see whether they are voluntarily obtained. And there have been some cases where such statements have been rejected.

    Sir, I do believe that a well-trained professional Police Force would want their statements taken by them to be admissible as evidence. I think checks and balances are in the system concerning the control of the Police and that they are accountable.

Column: 828



    Now I come to crime control in neighbourhoods. Sir, Singapore is fortunate to have a comparatively low crime rate. We must be one of the very few countries in the world that needs to advertise that low crime rate does not mean no crime. The Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) is a key institution in the fight against crime in Singapore. There are now 91 NPPs in Singapore. The NPP is the most visible link between the Police and the people. It forges ties between officers and residents and provides the latter with a real sense of security. The officers also get to know the neighbourhood well, adding to their ability to cope with local crime quickly. Since the start of the scheme in 1983, the NPP has gained a solid reputation among residents. It is usually the first recourse when residents want to report a crime or dispute. The fact that crime is generally low in the estates testifies to the success of the police in general and the NPP scheme in particular.

    Earlier this month, the Minister announced the setting up of three Neighbourhood Police Centres (NPCs) to provide better service to the residents; the first to be set up in October, the others in the first part of next year. Sir, the reasons reported for the redesign of the NPP scheme are said to be two-fold:

    First, expanding the duties of NPP officers will encourage better qualified persons to join the Police. Second, the new scheme will be more efficient in terms of using manpower resources. Whether the redesign will achieve these ends, of course, remains to be seen.

    In the meantime, there are several concerns that I hope the Minister can address. First, will the reorganisation mean that no new Neighbourhood Police Posts will be built? This is of particular concern to those who have just moved into new neighbourhoods. For example, Woodlands is still served by the Bukit Panjang NPP. It is natural for residents who have just moved to a new area, such as Neighbourhood 5 or 6 in Woodlands, to feel more insecure as they need time to adjust to the new environment. They, more than anyone else, in my experience, have requested for more police patrols.

Column: 829


1.00 pm

    Second, does the redesigned structure mean more or less visibility in terms of foot or bicycle patrols in the estates? It has to be recognised that one of the most effective deterrents against crime has been the presence of police officers in vulnerable areas. Fast response cars or car patrols may be more efficient, but not as effective in terms of police presence as men on foot patrols.

    Third, will the redesigning of the NPPs also take into account the fact that it is now possible to keep watch through the use of surveillance cameras? Surveillance equipment may be expensive but never as good as officers on the ground. However, they can be on 24 hours a day providing round the clock security. These cameras are already a common sight in some private properties here. Although they are used in public streets and facilities, it is much more widespread in other countries such as England. In the long run, such devices may help to alleviate the shortage of manpower in uniformed services, which was referred to by other MPs, while providing a high degree of security in areas monitored by such means. Of course, I do not mean to advocate that these devices are placed in such a manner as to intrude on the privacy of residents.

    Sir, it is worth emphasising in closing that the prevention of crime is not only the sole task of the police. It is even more important for all residents to be aware of the need for security. All too often, one finds that residents complain about petty thefts of their belongings left out in public corridors, claiming that the police have not done enough. The public needs to be aware that the control of crime is not just a matter for the police but it is the responsibility that is shared by all.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the speaker, by way of clarification, when he talks about interrogation methods of the police and the admissibility of statements, is he aware that in 1989 three men were alleged to have confessed to murder after

Column: 830

28 hours of interrogation when they were totally innocent and finally were acquitted by the court?

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: Sir, I believe that the courts and the law reports, which of course Mr Jeyaretnam, as a practising lawyer would be aware of, do document a number of cases where, because of persistent questioning and long hours of questioning, the statements have not been received in evidence. It is not just one case where the statements have been rejected. There have been rejections of statements on a number of occasions which, of course, Mr Jeyaretnam should know about.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: The statements were admitted in this case.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: But you do know many of the statements were not admitted.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, the upshot in juvenile delinquency, rioting and teen violence is a cause for concern. There is also a rise in the number of female delinquents. Contrary to popular belief that delinquency is a problem of broken homes, some of these delinquents seem to come from affluent families as well. They are at an age not to realise that if caught and charged for misdeamours it may result in an uncertain future. Hence, we must implement measures to prevent such young Singaporeans from having their careless behaviour criminalised.

    I therefore welcome the implementation of the ban on under-16s from tea dances and discos. This is but one measure. Another measure which should be considered is the implementation of a curfew on teenagers in selected popular locations. Young Singaporeans are drawn to the bright lights and reading media reports. There seems to be a trend in believing that it is fashionable for young people to be members of a gang.

    When enforcement measures are implemented, unfortunately, a breach will bring the young offender face to face with the law. A tough decision will then have to be made by the enforcement agency, which

Column: 831

is to prosecute or not to prosecute. Prosecution of a young offender is often viewed negatively, especially when a custodial sentence is imposed after conviction. Parents are inevitably the first persons to declare that their children are not bad or guilty, even when the evidence before them is overwhelming.

    Delinquents often cite parents' behaviour, such as neglect, abuse, indifference to over-indulgence or over-protectiveness or being too strict, as a cause for their behaviour. Such parents even blame the schools for their children's poor behaviour. What all this means is that delinquency and a host of other related problems are very much a multi-faceted one. By the time the police is involved, much harm has already taken place. The lucky ones may get away with a stern warning. But the not so fortunate ones will have their criminal records with them for the rest of their lives. Therefore, this issue is not strictly a police problem as many have mistakenly believed.

    I believe that an Inter-Ministry Committee has been put in place to look into this problem and the imposition of a ban on under-16s from discos and tea dances is only one measure to prevent the problem from escalating. It will be useful for the Minister to enlighten us on the workings of this Committee and elaborate on some of the possible measures that will be implemented to arrest this problem.

    Mr Kenneth Chen Koon Lap: Sir, the ban on teenagers below the age of 16 entering premises that sell liquor has received very positive response from parents, especially in view of the increasing incidence of reports where youngsters got beaten up by gangs and the increase in cases of teenagers being arrested for rioting. However, I wonder how effective this measure would be to prevent our youths from joining gangs and creating trouble, as they can always find other places to engage in such illegal activities. In fact, the source for recruiting generally innocent youths into gangs often happens in places such as void decks, shopping malls, schools and other such public

Column: 832

places. By the time they caused problems in these places, such as pubs and discos, the damage has already been done.

    In Singapore, very often both parents are working and are not able to spend sufficient time to monitor their children's activities. Once I was asked to give assistance to my constituents. Both husband and wife are professionals. They were shocked to discover that their son was arrested for rioting and being a member of a teenage gang. They have absolutely no prior knowledge of their son's activities. The son, being extremely timid, was intimidated into joining the gang by friends while hanging out in one of these areas.

    In the past, secret societies have effectively been wiped out. I am sure our Criminal Investigations Department (CID) is more than capable to do the same by tracking down the ring leaders of such youth gangs. Once these ring leaders are immobilised, all the so-called followers, most of whom are misguided youths and not hardcore criminals, would not be able to cause trouble on their own. Action has to be taken immediately before these gangs can take root and become as notorious as the secret societies of the past.

    Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar)(In Mandarin): Sir, over the past five years, I have been speaking on juvenile delinquency and every year I heard that new measures were taken to prevent juvenile delinquency. This is very encouraging. But I still feel that the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Police should not be the only agencies dealing with juvenile delinquency. I think this is a matter that involves the whole society - parents, schools and other social components. It is the common responsibility of all the people. So it is not right that the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Police should be asked to take the whole responsibility. It is not right for people to perceive this as such.

    I agree with my colleagues that prevention of juvenile delinquency should be handled by an Inter-Ministry Committee. It can be better solved

Column: 833

through such a Committee. Every year we have new measures. It does not mean that the question of juvenile delinquency is getting worse. It also means that our juvenile delinquents are becoming more sophisticated. The moment you have new measures they know how to circumvent them. When the number of delinquents arrested is declining, could it be because our juvenile delinquents have learned how to avoid being arrested? In any case, I appreciate Prof. Ho Peng Kee's announcement of the four measures earlier to curb juvenile delinquency.

    Here, I would like to ask the Minister a few questions. The Minister announced that from 1st October, young people below the age of 16 will be banned from attending tea dances? Why 16? Why cannot you include those below 18? Those below 18 should also be banned from going to discos and tea dances. In December last year, we imposed a ban on youngsters below 16 from going to the billiard saloons. We can increase the age restriction to 18.
